title: Pacers considering trading Paul George to Celtics
text:
Pacers considering trading Paul George to Celtics Nate Taylor , nate.taylor@indystar.com Published 2:54 p.m. ET Feb. 22, 2017 | Updated 13 minutes ago CLOSE Share Let's weigh the pros and cons. Nate Chute/IndyStar Paul George of Indiana, is defended by Danny Green, San Antonio Spurs at Indiana Pacers, Bankers Life Fieldhouse, Indianapolis, Monday, February 13, 2017. San Antonio won 110-106. (Photo: Robert Scheer/IndyStar) 408 CONNECT 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
INDIANAPOLIS — A day before the NBA trade deadline, the Indiana Pacers appear to be thinking about making a monumental shift in their philosophy. 
According to USA Today's Sam Amick , Paul George recently met with owner Herb Simon and told him he would like to go down as the greatest Pacer of them all, but with one qualifier: They have to be contending for a title. 
According to a person with knowledge of the meeting who spoke to USA Today Sports on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the situation, that has Pacers President Larry Bird facing a crossroads. 
On one front, the Pacers are trying to determine what they could receive from the Boston Celtics in exchange for George. 
The Celtics, who possess the lowly Brooklyn Nets’ first round picks in the next two drafts and a number of talented rotational players, are eager to acquire another star for a 37-20 team that is led by Isaiah Thomas in order to dethrone the defending champion Cleveland Cavaliers. The reason the Pacers would consider dealing George now, according to a report from The Vertical’s Adrian Wojnarowski , is that the Celtics have also been linked to Chicago's Jimmy Butler. A trade for Butler would take the Celtics -- the team with the most to offer in a deal -- out of the trade market. 
The Pacers, however, are also looking to make a trade to bring more talent to the roster to help George, Myles Turner and Jeff Teague in the second half of the season, which begins Friday against the Memphis Grizzlies. 
If the Pacers do trade George to the Celtics, it would signify an abrupt change in their initial plans to build a team around their star player that could compete in the Eastern Conference. Instead, a trade sending George to Boston would start a rebuilding process around Turner, the Pacers’ 20-year-old phenom center. 
Multiple sources Tuesday told IndyStar the Pacers would not consider any trade discussion that involved George. 
In January, Pacers President Larry Bird told IndyStar , “Before the year started, I told Paul, ‘Look, if you want to sign a long-term deal, we’re willing to do that max (contract) and if you want to wait, I understand.’ But this year, we’re not going to worry about it, we’re not going to talk about it and he’s going to make the decision that’s best for Paul when it comes down to it.” 
George has made no public comments this season that he is favor of a trade. George said Friday on ESPN radio that he wants to lead the Pacers to their first NBA championship. But he also has made it clear he wants to see the supporting players that Bird surrounds him with before making a decision on a long-term contract. 
“As I told Larry, I always want to play on a winning team,” George said on the program . He later added: “Man, I want a chance to play for a chance to win a championship.” 
George can opt out of his contract at the end of the 2017-18 season, which he is expected to do. 
The Pacers can’t offer the new designated player exception – which allows a team to offer a sixth-year on contract extensions, an extra 5 percent of the salary cap (35 versus 30) and larger raises (7.5 percent versus 4.5 percent) – unless George makes one of the three All-NBA teams after the season. 
In 50 games this season, George has averaged 22.3 points, 6.2 rebounds and 3.3 assists per game. 
If the exception applies, the Pacers can offer George a contract worth roughly $212.3 million over six seasons ; another team could offer approximately $123 million over four. 
If George is not traded, the Pacers’ best asset is their first-round pick. Bird is willing to trade the pick if it allows him to add another veteran who could help the Pacers in the playoffs. As far as acquiring talent, the Pacers have reached out to multiple teams to gauge who is available. 
Indiana entered the All-Star break last week on a six-game losing streak and currently holds the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference at 29-28.
